items.title: Man Drives Car Onto Sidewalk Outside L.A. City Hall, Barricading Himself Inside
items.summary: A man in a vehicle displaying a handwritten sign referring to President Trump refused to exit his car as the authorities shut down surrounding streets. The man was taken into custody.

items.title: Trump Administration Is Said to Plan to Cut Refugee Admissions to a Record Low
items.summary: Many of the slots would go to white South Africans and others facing “unjust discrimination,” according to people familiar with the matter and documents obtained by The New York Times.

items.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene Criticizes Senate Republicans for Government Shutdown
items.summary: In a social media post, the far-right Georgia congresswoman called on Senate Republicans to eliminate the filibuster, lowering the threshold on future legislation to a simple majority.

items.title: Federal Workers’ Union Sues Administration Over Partisan Email Language
items.summary: Department of Education employees this week found that their out-of-office emails during the government shutdown had been edited to include partisan language.

items.title: Journalist Mario Guevara Is Deported After Being Held Over 100 Days
items.summary: The Salvadoran journalist was arrested in June while covering a “No Kings” protest outside Atlanta. Those charges were dropped, his lawyers said.

items.title: Reaching for a Connection to Taylor Swift
items.summary: A Democrat in a crowded House primary in Colorado is far from the only politician grasping for Taylor Swift-related straws.

items.title: California measure brings rideshare drivers one step closer to unionizing
items.summary: <p>Governor Gavin Newsom signs measure opening path to more than 800,000 drivers to bargain for wages and benefits</p><p>More than 800,000 ride-hailing drivers in California will soon be able to join a union and negotiate for higher wages and better benefits under a measure signed Friday by the governor, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/gavin-newsom">Gavin Newsom</a>.</p><p>Supporters said the new law will open a path for the largest expansion of private-sector collective bargaining rights in the state’s history. The legislation is a significant compromise in the years-long battle between labor unions and tech companies.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/03/california-ride-hailing-drivers-union">Continue reading...</a>
